In this way, each type of sentient being also has twelve kinds of inversions;

In this world, the twelve types of beings are unable to sustain themselves and depend on the four foods to live, namely, solid food, contact food, intention food, and consciousness food. Therefore, the Buddha said that all sentient beings depend on food to live.

What is right nature?
Ä€nanda!

For practitioners, if they do not cut off lust and killing, there is no way to leave the three realms.

One should view sexual desire as if it were a poisonous snake or an enemy, first upholding the four grave and eight grave precepts of the Å›rÄvakas to keep the body unmoving, and later practicing the pure precepts of the bodhisattva to keep the mind unmoving. This pure person cultivating samÄdhi, with the physical body of parents, without needing the heavenly eye, naturally sees the worlds of the ten directions, sees the buddhas, hears the Dharma, personally receives the holy teachings, attains great spiritual powers, and roams in the realms of the ten directions. What is present karma?
Ä€nanda!

Thus, the mind of one who purely upholds the precepts is free from greed and lust, and does not flow out to the external six sense objects to a great extent. Because it does not flow out, it returns to the origin and reverts to the source. Since the sense objects are not relied upon, the faculties have nothing to which to correspond. The reversed flow completes the one, and the six functions do not operate. The lands of the ten directions are pure and clear, like a lapis lazuli through which the bright moon is suspended.

The body and mind are joyful, wondrous, perfect, and equal, and one attains great peace and security. All the TathÄgatas' secret, perfect, pure, and wondrous [natures] manifest within it. This person then attains the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas.
From here, gradually cultivating according to one's practice, one is established in the holy stages. This is called the third stage of gradual practice and progress.
Ä€nanda!

This good man, with the drying up of desire and love, the faculties and sense objects not corresponding, the remaining substance in the present not being reborn again, the grasping mind empty and clear, purely wisdom, the nature of wisdom bright and perfect, illuminating the worlds of the ten directions, having this wisdom while dry, is called the stage of dry wisdom.

When the first dry wisdom of desire is extinguished, but one has not yet been connected with the flowing water of the TathÄgata's Dharma, one immediately enters the middle of this mind and flows into the perfect marvelously blooming, from the true marvelously perfect again giving rise to the true marvelously perfect, with marvelous faith always abiding, all false thoughts extinguished without remainder, the middle way pure and true, called the stage of abiding in faith.

Truly believing and understanding all perfect penetration, the three of aggregates, sense bases, and elements cannot obstruct, like this, up to the countless eons of the past and future, abandoning the body and receiving the body, all habitual tendencies all appearing before one, this good man is all able to recollect, without forgetting, called the stage of abiding in recollection.

The marvelous perfect purity gives rise to the transformation of true essence, the habitual tendencies from beginningless time penetrating into a single essence of clarity, only using the essence of clarity to progress towards true purity, called the stage of abiding in the mind of vigor. The essence of the mind manifesting before one, purely using wisdom, called the stage of abiding in the mind of wisdom.
Upholding the clarity of wisdom, pervading everywhere in tranquil stillness, the marvelous stillness always condensing, called the stage of abiding in the mind of concentration.
The light of samÄdhi illuminates the nature of mind, penetrating deeply, only advancing without retreating, called the irreversible mind.
The mind advances peacefully, preserving and not losing it, the qi of the tathÄgatas of the ten directions interconnects, called the mind that protects the Dharma.

The enlightened mind preserves and can use wondrous power to turn the Buddha's compassionate light back to the Buddha and abide peacefully, like two mirrors with lights facing each other, the wondrous reflections within them entering each other repeatedly, called the mind of dedication.
The mind's light secretly turns back, attaining the Buddha's eternal, unsurpassed, wondrous purity, peacefully abiding in the unconditioned and not losing anything, called the mind of precepts.
Abiding in the precepts freely, able to travel to the ten directions, going wherever one wishes, called the mind of aspiration.
Ä€nanda!

This good man, with true skillful means, gives rise to these ten minds. The essence of the mind is manifested, and the ten functions enter into each other, perfectly forming one mind, called the abiding of giving rise to the mind.
The mind becomes clear like pure lapis lazuli, and the essence is revealed like refined gold. Using this wondrous mind to tread and form the ground is called the Abode of Treading the Ground.
The mind-ground and knowledge are both clearly understood, and one can roam the ten directions without obstruction, called the Abode of Cultivating Practice.

Practice is the same as the Buddha's, and one receives the Buddha's energy, like a body in the intermediate state seeking its parents. The hidden faith secretly penetrates and enters the TathÄgata's lineage, called the Abode of Noble Birth.

Having already entered the womb of the Way and personally served the Buddha's offspring, like a fetus that has already taken on human characteristics without deficiency, it is called the Abode of Skillful Means.
Having the same appearance and mind as the Buddha, it is called the Abode of Right Mind.
Body and mind combine and increase day by day, called the Abode of Non-retrogression.
The ten bodies and spiritual characteristics are all complete at once, called the Abode of the Youthful Sage.
Having taken on human form and personally becoming the Buddha's child, it is called the Abode of the Crown Prince of the Dharma.

It is like a great king of a country who entrusts the affairs of the country to his crown prince. The prince of a kshatriya king, when he comes of age, is anointed with ablution, called the stage of ablution.
Ä€nanda!
This good man, having become a Buddha's disciple, fully possesses the immeasurable wonderful virtues of the TathÄgata, and is in accord with the ten directions, called the practice of joy.

Awakening oneself and awakening others, without obstruction, is called the practice of being free from anger and resentment.
Giving rise to various kinds, exhausting the future, the three times are equal, and the ten directions are penetrated, called the practice of being inexhaustible.
All are the same, and various Dharma gates are free from error, called the practice of being free from delusion and confusion.
Then, within the same, many differences are manifested, and each different characteristic sees the same, called the practice of skillful manifestation.

In this way, up to the ten directions of space filled with fine dust motes, each dust mote manifesting the worlds of the ten directions, the manifestation of dust motes and worlds not obstructing each other, is called the practice of non-attachment.

Ä€nanda!

When these good men have perfected spiritual powers and accomplished the Buddha's work, pure and genuine, far removed from the affliction of remaining, they should deliver sentient beings and eliminate the notion of deliverance, turning the unconditioned mind towards the path of nirvÄá¹‡a, called the dedication of saving all sentient beings and being free from the notion of sentient beings.

When the true roots are established, the beings of the ten directions are all my original nature. The nature is perfectly accomplished without losing sentient beings, named the Ground of Following and Conforming to the Equal Observation of All Sentient Beings.

The mind and the Buddha are both the same, skillfully attaining the middle way, like a person enduring something, neither holding it in nor releasing it, is called the stage of endurance.

Ä€nanda!
These good men skillfully attain thorough understanding in great enlightenment, and awaken to the interpenetration of the TathÄgata's complete Buddha realm, called the stage of joy.

Like the bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« Jewel Lotus Fragrance, who upheld the bodhisattva precepts but privately engaged in sexual activity, falsely claiming that engaging in sex is neither killing, nor stealing, and has no karmic retribution. Do they each give rise to karma and privately experience their own retribution? Please bestow great compassion and enlighten the ignorant, so that all sentient beings who uphold the precepts will hear the definitive truth, joyfully accept it on their heads, and be scrupulous in their observance without transgression.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
This question is excellent!
Causing sentient beings not to enter wrong views.
You should listen attentively now!
I will explain it for you.
Ä€nanda!
All sentient beings are originally truly pure, but due to deluded views, deluded habits arise. Based on this, the inner and outer divisions are separated.
Ä€nanda!

The inner division is the inner part of sentient beings. Due to various attachments, deluded emotions arise. If these emotions accumulate without cease, they can give rise to the water of love. Therefore, when the mind thinks of delicious food, saliva comes out of the mouth. When the mind thinks of someone with affection or resentment, tears fill the eyes. When greedily seeking wealth and treasures, the mind produces loving saliva and the whole body becomes lustrous. When the mind is attached to sexual activity, the two sexual organs naturally secrete fluids.
Ä€nanda!
Although the various loves are different, the flowing bonds are the same. Wetness does not rise but naturally falls. This is called the inner division.
Ä€nanda!

The external part refers to the external part of sentient beings. Due to various yearnings, illusory thoughts are manifested. If thoughts accumulate without ceasing, they can give rise to superior energy. Therefore, if one's mind upholds precepts, the whole body feels light and pure. If one's mind holds mantras and mudras, one's glances become bold and resolute. If one's mind wishes to be reborn in the heavens, one's dreams will be of flying and soaring. If one's mind dwells in the Buddha-lands, the sacred realms will appear mysteriously. If one serves spiritual friends, one will devalue one's own body and life.
Ä€nanda!
Although the various thoughts are different, lightness and elevation are the same. Flying and moving without sinking naturally transcends [the mundane]. This is called the external part.
Ä€nanda!

In all worlds, the continuation of birth and death is such that life follows habitual tendencies and death follows changes and transformations. At the moment of death, before the warmth of the body is lost, the good and evil of one's entire life suddenly manifest simultaneously. Death goes against life, and the two habitual tendencies of life and death intersect. If one's thoughts are pure and one flies, one will definitely be reborn in the heavens. If in the midst of flying, one combines blessings, wisdom, and pure vows, one's mind will naturally open and one will see the buddhas of the ten directions. One can be reborn in any pure land according to one's wishes.

Those with little emotion and much thought rise lightly and do not go far, becoming flying immortals, powerful ghost kings, flying yakshas, and ground-roaming rakshasas, roaming the four heavens unimpeded. Among them, if there are those with good aspirations and good minds who uphold my Dharma, or who protect the precepts and follow those who uphold the precepts, or who protect divine spells and follow those who uphold spells, or who protect meditation and support the acceptance of the Dharma, these will dwell close to the Tathagata's seat;
Those with equal emotion and thought do not fly or fall, but are born among humans. The bright thoughts make them wise, and the dark emotions make them dull.
Those with much emotion and little thought flow into sideways births, becoming heavy as beasts and light as birds;

Those with seven emotions and three thoughts sink into the water wheel and are born at the edge of fire, receiving the qi of fierce fire. Their bodies become hungry ghosts, constantly burned by fire, and water can harm them. Without food or drink, they pass through hundreds of thousands of kalpas.

Nine feelings and one thought lead to the fire wheel below, where the body enters the ground between wind and fire, and gives rise to the two hells of light life, intermittent rebirth, and heavy life, uninterrupted rebirth.

Pure feeling immediately sinks into the AvÄ«ci hell. If one sinks in the mind and slanders the MahÄyÄna, slanders the Buddha's precepts, deceives and falsely preaches the Dharma, greedily accepts offerings of faith, and falsely receives respect, and commits the five heinous crimes and the ten grave offenses, one will be reborn in the AvÄ«ci hells of the ten directions.
Although one follows one's own evil karma and invites it upon oneself, in the common destiny of the multitude there is also an original basis.
Ä€nanda!
All of these are caused by the karma of those sentient beings themselves. They create ten habitual causes and receive six reciprocal retributions.
What are the ten causes?
Ä€nanda!

First, the habit of lust and mutual contact arises from mutual friction. Grinding and rubbing without rest, thus there is a great fierce fire light that arises in it. It is like a person using their hands to rub each other, and the sign of warmth appears before them;
The two habits give rise to each other, and thus there are iron beds and copper pillars and other things.
Therefore, the Tathagatas of the ten directions regard sexual activity as having the same name as the fire of desire;
Bodhisattvas view desire as if avoiding a pit of fire.

Second, the habit of greed arises from mutual calculation, giving rise to mutual attraction, sucking and grasping without stopping. Thus there is accumulated cold and solid ice in which one freezes, just as when a person sucks in air with their mouth, a cold sensation arises.
The two habits oppress each other, and thus there are the sounds of 'cha cha,' 'pa pa,' 'la la,' blue, red, and white lotuses, cold ice, and other things.
Therefore, the Tathagatas of the ten directions regard excessive seeking as having the same name as the water of greed;
Bodhisattvas view greed as if avoiding a poisonous sea.

Third, the habit of arrogance arises from mutual oppression, giving rise to mutual reliance, running and flowing without ceasing. Thus there is soaring and rushing, accumulating waves to form water, just as when a person's mouth and tongue repeatedly taste each other, causing saliva to flow;
The two habits interact, resulting in the affairs of blood rivers, ash rivers, hot sand, poisonous seas, and molten copper poured to be swallowed.
Therefore, all TathÄgatas in the ten directions regard arrogance as drinking water of delusion;
Bodhisattvas view arrogance as avoiding a great drowning.

Fourth, the habit energy of anger colliding, arising from mutual resentment, the resentment knot not ceasing, the mind hot and giving rise to fire, casting qi as gold, thus there are knife mountains, iron stakes, sword trees, sword wheels, axes, spears, and saws, like a person holding grudges with killing qi flying about;
The two habits strike each other, resulting in the affairs of palaces, cutting, slicing, chopping, sawing, stabbing, beating, and striking.
Therefore, all TathÄgatas in the ten directions regard anger as a sharp knife;
Bodhisattvas view anger as avoiding execution.

Fifth, the habit energy of deception and flattery, which arises from mutual flattery and leads to incessant agitation, thus resulting in ropes, wood, binding, and torture, like grass and trees growing in waterlogged fields;
these two habit energies extend to each other, thus there are affairs such as handcuffs, shackles, whips, canes, and beatings.
Therefore, all TathÄgatas of the ten directions regard deceit and flattery as being the same as slander and theft;
bodhisattvas view deception as if fearing a wolf.

Sixth, the habit energy of deception and fraud, which arises from mutual deception and leads to incessant false accusations and flying thoughts creating schemes, thus resulting in dust, dirt, feces, urine, filth, and impurity, like dust following the wind with nothing to be seen;
these two habit energies reinforce each other, thus there are affairs such as drowning, throwing up, flying down, and drifting.
Therefore, all TathÄgatas of the ten directions regard deception and fraud as being the same as robbery and killing;
bodhisattvas view deception as if treading on a snake or viper.

Seventh, the habitual resentment of enemies, arising from grudges, leads to the existence of flying stones, hurled projectiles, boxes, carts, jars, sacks, and beatings, like a treacherous person harboring evil in their heart.
These two habits swallow each other, leading to the activities of throwing, catching, striking, shooting, and grabbing.
Therefore, all TathÄgatas in the ten directions regard enemies as harmful ghosts;
Bodhisattvas view enemies as if drinking poison.

Eighth, the mutual illumination of views, such as the view of the aggregates, the view of precepts and observances, and the various activities of wrong enlightenment, arise from opposition and mutual exclusion, leading to the existence of royal messengers, officials, witnesses, and written records;

like travelers coming and going, seeing each other, these two habits interact, leading to the activities of interrogation, deception, investigation, examination, inquiry, and investigation, illuminating good and evil, with children holding written records and arguing with words.
Therefore, all TathÄgatas of the ten directions regard evil views as the pit of views;
Bodhisattvas see all false and pervasive attachments as entering a pit of poison.

Ninth, the habit energy of slander and accusation, which arises from false accusations and slander. Thus, there are the hells of mountains and rocks coming together, grinding, plowing, and polishing, like a treacherous person oppressing the innocent.
These two habit energies push against each other, resulting in the various activities of pressing, kneading, beating, pressing, squeezing, and weighing.
Therefore, all TathÄgatas of the ten directions regard resentment and slander as the tiger of slander;
Bodhisattvas see slander as if struck by lightning.
Tenth, the habit energy of litigation and argument, which arises from concealment. Thus, there are mirrors that reflect and illuminate, like shadows that cannot be hidden in the sun;
Therefore, there are evil friends, mirrors of karma, and fire-like jewels that reveal past karma and verify various events.
Therefore, all TathÄgatas of the ten directions regard concealment as the thief in the dark;
Bodhisattvas view concealment as wearing a mountain on their head and walking on a great ocean.
What are the six retributions?
Ä€nanda!
All sentient beings create karma with their six consciousnesses, and the evil retributions they attract come from their six sense faculties.
How do evil retributions come from the six sense faculties?
First, the retribution of seeing attracts evil results.

Burning breath can become black smoke and purple flames;ğŸ”½Burning taste can become charred pellets and iron gruel;

Fourth, the retribution of taste attracts evil consequences.

When the karma of taste comes to fruition, at the end of life one first sees an iron net with fierce flames covering the world. The dying person's spirit penetrates downward through the net, hanging upside down, and enters the AvÄ«ci Hell, manifesting two signs:

Experiencing seeing can cause burning of metal and stone;
Experiencing hearing can cause sharp weapons;
Experiencing breath can cause a great iron cage to cover the country;
Experiencing touch can cause bows, arrows, crossbows, and guns;
Experiencing thought can cause flying hot iron to rain down from the sky.
Fifth, the retribution of touch attracts evil consequences.

When the karma of this touch is about to be exhausted, before death one will first see four mountains coming together from all sides, with no way out. The deceased's consciousness will see a great iron city, with fire-snakes, fire-dogs, tigers, wolves, lions, ox-headed guards, and horse-headed rÄká¹£asas wielding spears and halberds, driving them into the city gates towards the AvÄ«ci Hell, manifesting two appearances:
